div.p: Bibliothèque des Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques, Geneva.

Trans. 6.9.94. To proof.
On board of the "Assam",

When returning from a phytographic excursion to Shark Bay and other portions of West Australia, dear M. De Candolle, I received your friendly letter of 22 Sept
Letter not found. at K George's Sound,
WA. and now on my return voyage to Melbourne I beg to thank for your goodness & generous & encouraging expressions. In my enquiry about the plan for the "monographiae phanerogamarum" & my offer to aid such a grand work, I thought that especially the families of plants, which your immortal father elaborated half a century ago would be reissued from the vastly increased material. Thus the great order of Myrtaceae would occupy a volume alone, and its elaboration would likely require two investigators, one who had studied the baccate Myrtaceae in tropical climes by personal experiences, an other who was familiar with most of the xerocarpic Myrtaceae by fieldwork. As the latter are represented mainly in Australia, and as large additions have been made to even the Australian Myrtaceae since Mr Bentham about a dozen years ago issued with my help the 3th vol. of the flora Australiensis,
Bentham (1863-78), vol 3. I was willing to work out anew that large group of plants for the "monographiae", if you deemed it desirable. I would not accept any remuneration for my manuscripts. Mr Bentham at his venerable age could not spare time away from the "genera".
Bentham & Hooker (1862-83). The Eucalypti require a very careful revision, and indeed all the Myrtaceae have in later years been traced over a much wider area, about 50 species have been added, and some changes been made, which my personal presence in Australia indicated, and which Mr Bentham in his excellent investigations would have likely adopted, had he had the advantage of travelling extensively over Australia.

Other families require a revision, e.g. Stackhousiaceae, to which the remarkable genus Macgregoria has been added. Other orders of the earlier volumes of the flora Australiensis
Bentham (1863-78), need revising also.

A sad loss, that of Parlatore! so unexpected too! I hoped to enjoy a voyage to Europe and then to meet also that great man. Alas, so I never shall meet him, Sir W. Hooker, Martius, Brogniart,
i.e. Brongniart. Braun, Miquel, — but I hope providence will spare me to see you, Hooker, Bentham, Decaisne & Goeppert some day
